reviewText:
Poverty Row Pictures presents "COME ON, TARZAN" (11 September 1932) (61 mins/B&W) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) -- . Ken Maynard was an American motion picture stuntman and actor --- Born Kenneth Olin Maynard in Vevay, Indiana, he was an accomplished horseman --- As a young man, he performed in rodeos and was a trick rider with Buffalo Bill 's Wild West Show and a circus rider with Ringling Brothers --- During World War I, he served in the United States Army.

He first appeared in silent motion pictures in 1923 and in addition to acting also did stunt work --- Maynard became one of the first singing cowboys with Columbia Records --- Also one of the first to make a star out of his white stallion named "Tarzan", a half-Arabian, half-American Saddle horse. Maynard bought him in the mid-1920's --- With his white cowboy hat, fancy shirt, and pair of six-shooters, from the 1920s to the mid-1940s --- Maynard appeared in more than 90 films --- However, his alcoholism severely impacted his life and his career ended in 1944. He owned a small circus operation featuring rodeo riders but eventually lost it to creditors.

The significant amount of money he had earned vanished and he lived a desolate life in a rundown mobile home --- During these years, Maynard was supported by an unknown admirer - long thought to be Gene Autry --- More than 25 years after his last starring role, Maynard returned to two small parts in films in 1970 and 1972 --- Ken Maynard died penniless in 1973 at the Motion Picture Home in Woodland Hills, California. He was interred at Forest Lawn Cypress Cemetery in Cypress, California. Maynard's funeral is described in detail in James Horwitz's book They Went Thataway --- His brother, Kermit Maynard, was also an actor and stuntman

For his contribution to the motion picture industry, Ken Maynard has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame at 6751 Hollywood Blvd -- (From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia)

Under the production staff of:
Alan James - Director / Screenwriter
Sam Bischoff - Producer
Burt Kelly - Producer
William Saal - Producer

Our story line and plot, Opening scenes has Steve Frazier (Niles Welch) and his gang rustling horses --- What happens when the wild horse Tarzan frees Frazier's rustled horses --- Frazier gets the Sheriff (Jack Rockwell) to declare Tarzan an outlaw and have him shot --- This brings Ken Benson (Ken Maynard) into action and he now tries to protect his favorite friend Tarzan from harm --- By far the best Ken Maynard effort from low-budget producer Sam Bischoff, almost wall-to-wall action in this over the top oater --- In this tightly paced Ken Maynard western (one of nine he made in 1932), the cowboy star's amazing riding skills are on impressive display. As a child, Maynard copied all the stunts he saw in circuses, and at age 14, ran away from home to join a wagon show. Maynard finally entered the movies in 1923 after working as a trick rider with the Buffalo Bill and Ringling Brothers Wild West shows --- Ken Maynard had been a major star in the 1920's famous for his trick riding and daring subnetwork. Unfortunately he had a few too many personal demons and his career steadily declined during the 1930s. This film is from his final solo starring series. He would re-surface briefly over weight and as nasty as ever in the 40s in Monogram's "Trail Blazer" with Hoot Gibson and Bob Steele --- After that he basically "retired" from the screen.

the cast includes:
Ken Maynard ... Ken Benson
Tarzan ... Tarzan, a wild horse
Merna Kennedy ... Pat Riley
Niles Welch ... Steve Frasier
Roy Stewart ... Henchman Butch
Kate Campbell ... Aunt Martha
Bob Kortman ... Henchman Spike Collins
Nelson McDowell ... Cowhand Slim
Jack Rockwell ... Sheriff
Hank Bell ... Cowhand Hank
Bob Burns ... Rancher Bob
Edmund Cobb ... Cowhand 'Injun'
Ben Corbett ... Cowhand Shorty
Jim Corey ... Cowhand Jim
Al Taylor ... Henchman Al
Robert Walker ... Cowhand
Blackjack Ward ... Henchman Jack
Slim Whitaker ... Henchman Slim

SPECIAL FEATURES:
BIO:
1. Ken Maynard (aka: Kenneth Olin Maynard)
Date of Birth: 21 July 1895 - Vevay, Indiana
Date of Death: 23 March 1973 - Woodland Hills, Los Angeles, California

If you crave action, drama and plenty of adventure check out other western double features --- Ask Amazon. Com to carry the volumes as they are not available on Amazon as of yet --- you can order and pick up your copy now from VCI Entertainment

KEN MAYNARD WESTERN DOUBLE FEATURE
Vol 1: Phantom Thunderbolt & Lightning Strikes West (VCI #7240) (DVD)
Vol 2: Dynamite Ranch & Death Rides the Range (VCI #7295) (DVD)
Vol 3: Drum Taps & Two Gun Man (VCI #7300) (DVD)
Vol 4: Fargo Express & Harmony Trail (VCI #7284) (DVD)
Vol 5: Western Courage & Whistlin' Dan (VCI #7307) (DVD)
Vol 6: In Old Santa Fe & Come On Tarzan (VCI #7346) (DVD)
Vol 7: Boots of Destiny & Flamin' Lead (VCI #7348) (DVD)
Vol 8: Six Shootin' Sheriff & Trailin' Trouble (VCI #7350) (DVD)

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc) and Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- If you're into the memories of B-Westerns with high drama, this is the one you've been anxiously waiting for --- please stand up and take a bow Western Classics --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 61 min on VHS/DVD ~ Poverty Row Pictures ~ (2/14/2008)

Total Time: 59 min on VHS/DVD ~ Poverty Row Pictures ~ (5/27/2008)
Even for a old movie, this is bad.
this was to be ordered by my wife for me before she passed on, i lov it very much thank you and may you be blessed. george
Once upon a time in the Real West!
The film quality was extremely poor and the sound wasn't much better. The write up said it was about a very smart horse named Tarzan but very little of the horse was in the movie.

This movie shows a great depiction of what cowboys and ranch life was like during the late 20's and early 39's. It also shows a realistic treatment of women in the west, good and bad. Movies like this need to be viewed for their historic value.

Great old Western. Gotta love the stunts in the chase scenes at the end. Interesting story line about killing horses for pet food and how  things have changed politically about that and wild horses since then.
I like the old movies and this is a keeper. It was funny, exciting, romantic. In the end, the good guy wins.
I like this movie because it is old and fun.  You don't have to think a lot when you watch it.  It is purely entertaining like movies used to be.  Any age could watch it.

I enjoyed the movie since the theme is based on fact and the fighting and horse back riding with the intense dust is so much closer to real life than most new films, there is a scene where an actor backs into a real bayonet plant and it is unscripted and you may miss it if you are not paying attention. If you like old westerns, then you will not be disappointed with this one.

A memorable introduction to Ken Maynard and his famous palomino. One of the cowboy star's best efforts, "Come On, Tarzan" (1932) benefits from an offbeat storyline and Ken's expert riding. Alan James directs in rustic fashion. Co-star Merna Kennedy was Charlie Chaplin's leading lady in "The Circus" (1928).

Most of the stunts seem to be done by Maynard himself. Wonderful old oater, even if you have to put up with some "Love in the Golden West."
stopped working about 7 minutes into the movie...Total failure... The Credits were nice
I like e old movies but this one is a bit too old.

Fun B-Western! Well done with a good cast ...especially Jack Rockwell as the sheriff a role he played about 40 times. Tarzan the horse, might have been more popular than Maynard with the Saturday Matinee crowd of kids...but Maynard and that singing ...had to go. And it did.
stunk.
enjoyed Ken Maynard, Come On, Tarzan
Old western,set in the 1930's.
Old black and white movie. Poor picture and sound quality.
Not very good at all.
old western, but good !
